title: Transformation of educational process in digital era
segmentation: So good morning.
Thank you very much again for the opportunity to speak today.
Dear Rector Servotronic, also other rectors and members of the Rectors Conference.
Here in Slovenia.
Dear colleagues.
I have the chance today to present some ideas we've been developing on the future of higher education, which we've developed for the German government, but with an international outlook.
Anne and.
An interesting enough I. I'm presenting this as a piece of research, but you'll see already here.
It says I'm a senior researcher at Kieran Open Education.
The care on platform is a way of is it.

It's a way of providing digital learning to help refugees get into higher education and this is a little bit of my idea that after I've developed this kind of steady on what the future should look like, I'd like to get my hands dirty and try and make the future happen.
Just maybe one thing on this picture you see here on the on the right hand side I was stuck very recently in.
Manheim because my train was delayed and often if I get stuck in a city, I like to see if there's a University nearby and just pop in and see what it's like.
The really interesting thing is above this above the ceiling.
Here in the picture was an auditorium where there was electric going on and there were hardly any students in that lecture.

Underneath here in this space it was totally full of students working with each other and I think this is one of the things that we have to think in higher education about how students are learning now because things are changing already an otherwise we're going to miss some of these changes, and so this was really one of the ideas behind the study we did for the German government and also just to tell you.
When I arranged to do this talk months ago, I had presumed that the study I'm going to present to you would have been released months ago.
In fact, the official release date is today.
So yesterday I did an interview on German radio this morning.
There's at least one article in the German newspapers about this study, so this is really fresh and hot off the press for you.
So.

I'll come back a little bit to this idea that we have used games to talk about what the future of higher education might be like, but I already think that this idea is quite nice, which is often when we think of higher education.
We're thinking very much of a closed space.
Normally it's a campus.
In fact, if we're thinking of digital learning, we often think of this being the screen in front of the student and maybe something behind it.
This is rather a closed idea of education, and so will come on later today on what the further ideas could be, but it's this idea well.
Does this really work for students?
And in fact, is this really how students are working so very often when I talk to policy makers, they presume that students are all working on their studies full time.
They only focus on studies, but we know for research from research for the last 20 years.
This isn't the case.
Students study along time alongside doing many other things, and it's going to be more and more important to recognize this and I'll come on to that.
We have a double challenge now.
We have to think about our students learning or acquiring the right skills for the future in a digital environment.
And we also have to think about how can we make learning more flexible by thinking of new pathways through learning.
And.
Just one of the studies which is being produced at the moment on the future of higher education I thought was quite useful.
This is something coming from the UK.
The main point about this study where they're talking about solving future skills challenges is they say we have to get away from the linear model of understanding that a young person finishes.
School goes to University says.
I'm finished with University and works.
We are moving more and more away from that, but also if we start moving away from that idea, we can also make higher education more inclusive as well.
Just really, because I want to.
Go through these a little bit quickly.

The slides will be available to you afterwards as well, but just really to show we are already seeing changes in the skills demands on the labor market and if you just look here, this is an analysis as done has been done by the OECD and all you really have to look at is this top level here of the skills written expression, written comprehension, deductive reasoning there according to their analysis.
That's where the skills gaps are at the moment in the labor market.
Now you will recognize those because really, there what we are often calling 21st century skills.
So it's about having digital information literacy.
It's about being creative and it's about developing collaborative skills, so we have to ask ourselves, are we offering within higher education an environment which promotes this kind of skills?
If we look, there's a lot of studies at the moment or change.
Changes that are going to happen.
The labor labor market.

I just want to give one indication of this study and just one particular thing here which says about 1/3 of people in the labor market at the moment in countries such as Germany are going to have to change their occupation between now and 2030.
So the question is how can we make that happen and how can higher education promote that happening?
The big change with?
Digitalization and moving to what we call in Germany at least.
Industry 4.0 is that in fact the skills demands on people are actually going up, and so we really have to go back and think about what is learning.
How can we create learning environments which can really be inclusive and can help everyone?
Particularly these people who are who are going to have to make changes in their career.
And if you see this, you see that it's right that.
We can't think of a purely linear way of going through an education system, which is what we tend to do at the moment.
And he had just again an indication to say what I'm going to be.

This is one of them, where they're essentially saying that there's going to be certain periods in somebody's life where.
Because of technical developments, but not only that.
Also social development.
They're going to need an additional period of learning.
So the study I'm talking about today is called ahead.
It's a study for the German government.
We have a small English language summary.
We're hoping in the not too distant future to have a link English language version of the study, but it hasn't been possible at the minute.
The most important thing is we were asked really to look forward to 2030 to say how we thought higher education might look.
Given.
Digital developments and in fact the ministrie.
So our client was a little bit surprised when we said, OK, we're not going to focus on digital first.
First, we're going to think about the thing we really know is going to change, which is learners pathways.
Then we're going to think about how digitalization can promote that and can help that and they were a little bit surprised 'cause they expected a more of a kind of a digital technical type study.
But in fact, they're already talking about this as being much more useful for them, and so This is why we particularly focused on putting the learner first.
And the other thing we did by putting the learner first is we firstly ignored the question of what will the institution University look like.

Most foresight studies focus on that and that is a mistake because as soon as you do that, you get to the big questions like how we're going to fund it, how it will quality assurance be organized, how we're going to regulate the system.
These are all important questions, but we should come to them second and not they shouldn't be the first focus.
Focus first should be on the learner.
So.
Here are.
The four pathways we've developed and then in a minute I'll talk about the individual models.
As you can see here, the first model, we've called Tamagotchi, so we gave all the four models the name of a toy.
This is a little bit just because we thought it's easy to remember.
It's just also a bit of fun, but the the analogies work relatively well, but here the idea is this is our classic system.
I'll talk about it a bit in a minute, but really, this is our classic idea, which the student they leave school and what you see here is this block.
They do one block of learning at the moment.
This is in most countries.
The Bachelor and the Masters?
That's a block.
Then they leave higher education and they say finish and I can tell you my daughter is currently finishing her Masters.
I was just helping her with her with rereading her thesis just yesterday.
She thinks she lives in this model.
I'm trying to tell her that's not the case.
You know, because changes will happen, but this is it's to do with the way we built the system.
So even the young people are still thinking that in this type of model.
So the three other models are kind of looking at this idea, but really breaking up the pathway.
The first model is called Jenga.
The idea with Jenga you'll see a picture of the toy a minute as well.
In case you don't know, some of these toys and the idea with Gengar is this first block of higher education could be shorter, and we can talk about that in a minute.
And then, though it already assumes that further blocks of higher education will come along the line during a person's lifespan.
The third model, you won't be surprised about.
We've called Lego.
It's really quite a different model where it's lots of different blocks of learning.
Again, I'll talk about it in a bit more detail in a minute.
The fourth model.
Doesn't look as radical as it actually is.
The reason is because we don't treat it as radical as it is.
We have lots of countries which have been working on providing higher education for mature learners, and here this block we have at the beginning.
This is the the person has left school.
They most probably have gone into vocational education and they've worked for a period.
They could have gone to higher education.

That's another possibility, but then they come to this new block of higher education with a whole bunch of experiences, and knowledge is, and we often just ignore that, and we treat the mature learners as if they are in the first model.
And This is why this model is actually highly relevant as well.
So let's just walk very briefly through the models.
So this is the timer.
Richie model now.
Let me just talk about four aspects which I talk about for each of them.
The idea here is that tertiary education is a fundamental way of learning skills and knowledge which makes the graduate futureproof.
This is often discussed when we talk about graduate attributes.
There is an implicit implicit assumption that during this.

You've learned many, many skills which make you highly adaptable, which means that if your career does change, you can adapt to that based on what you've learned already in in tertiary education, and this does work.
The question is, does it work for enough people, and will it continue to work into the future?
And as you know, the one of the classic problems with this model is we're always confronted by the labor market saying.
There are skill gaps because what I want as as an employer is not what the University is providing and this is a little bit to do with the fact of the idea that it's one block, and then you're done.
So in the didactics here, this is a very good model for young people who need a lot of support who need orientation.
So this hi dear of whole idea of building an ecosystem, having students on campus, making them feel.
A certain identity as part of the University.
This is useful for a lot of students, but the didactical model essentially is built on this idea that it's enclosed.
We help the student to kind of.
Develop their initial personality and skills which will help them into the future.
The technology here.
Normally when we talk about technological change at the moment in digitalization, it's always being applied to this kind of model.
So this is when we see people saying, OK, we're doing blended learning.

We are also introducing certain aspects of augmented reality, perhaps, and simulations, but you often find, and this is not just the case in Germany that this is happening mostly by individual champions in universities who are pushing these things, but it's very hard to.
Develop that on a strategic, national, strategic, institutional scale so the technology will be changing over the past over the next 10 to 12 years for sure.

But yesterday in the Radio One of my major points was we need to be more experimental and with this model it's a little bit difficult to be experimental because we're not really changing the organizational structure.
So if we then go forward to Django now, you can see here almost adaptable process happening here on the right.

So Jenga, if you don't know it, it's it's about building this kind of tower and the point of this is our idea here is the different colors are kind of different subject areas or different knowledge blocks which are being put together.

But you can see here partly what we're saying is maybe not everything has to be done in this first block, and then you can also see here once their tower is built, then we start taking some things out because we say they can be learned later.
So the idea behind this model is to try and think about what is the thing that's really fundamentally important in a study.
Maybe we can do this also in two year courses.
So short cycle programs are certainly growing throughout Europe.
The most important thing though for this.
Our model is that when we think of didactics and we think of program design.

What does the whole program look like?

So the interesting thing is here, what role will universities play in this?
Because these extra blocks they can be offered by other providers, but it could be that the University is the one that credits.
Watch being learned in different phases.

You can make all these connections so really here it's a question of.
Could we have some kind of XR re services?
Also this could be provided by universities which are offering advice on how to make these different connections and.

What we find is this is happening a little bit already in the job market, especially in areas where new skills are being expected all of the time, and the University system hasn't really caught up with it.
A good example from the past in Germany has been in computer science because we realized very quickly in Germany maybe about 10 years ago.
We have a huge gap in the skills of on the on the market in terms of IT skills.

So the first thing that happened is a very much kind of informal way of organizing the whole thing, where students will be doing various courses and employers would say, OK. Well, I I see how that all fits together.
I'll take you on.
What's happened in Germany is this has become more formalized, and in fact this whole kind of flexibility.
Has now become less and less flexible because everyone saw this as a temporary model and the question is, is this a temporary model or is it for certain areas a very important model?
But again, of course, here we have the question of how do we assure quality?
How do we make sure that we steer the system in a certain way?

We need employers to be playing a big role in this model, so there's a huge interaction, I think between employers and higher education providers here, and we have to make sure that this system isn't wholly exclusive because we need to understand part of didactics is supervision an advice which.
Tends to be part of our didactics also in the classroom, but it tends to be something we just assume, but we don't focus on.
And the more we think about more flexible models, the more we have to think of part of the tactics.
Is this advice piece.

Um?
Firstly, this is going to be highly important.
We have had huge expansion of participation in higher education over the last 20 years, but higher education is still exclusive.

We still have very few people who come from first who are first generation students, so it tends to be a great predictor of whether you go to University of whether your parents have been to University before.
This is not going to work in a digital world where the skills demand on individual people are going up.
We need to rethink about this and also we need to think about the fact that often we think of this kind of change in later life as something that can be done with further education.
There is almost no country in the world where further education is thought of systematically.
It's often very fragmented.
It's not really governed by by systematic policy, and so we have to think about how we can deal with that.
And one of our arguments is let's pull that into tertiary education or into higher education.
So let's let's try and get away from the idea that higher education is one thing and further education is something else.
But we pull that in together.
Which will mean of course we have more diversity, but it will mean we can support this kind of empowerment process, which is important.
So we see this happening that people are coming to higher education over the age of 30 in many countries, but the group is too small and also in terms of didactics.
I've already mentioned it.

So finally, really just this is, you know, everything everything from there the the learner perspective in a certain way.
But now we have to think about or how could we actually move forward.
And of course, that means we have to think about.
The institution or the provision of higher education.
And so we've said, now the changes which are happening is we are looking at changes in the knowledge and competency required on the labor market.
We see changes in technology which, in terms of Labor market change is creating new profile demands.
But technology can also be used to provide and support some of the processes in higher education which I've already mentioned.
Demography, of course, right across Europe and beyond is a huge issue.
We have less young people, which means we must anyway move beyond the idea that students are those who are 18 to 22.
That's just not sustainable anymore.
And the job market is also becoming much more dynamic.
More people are working freelance, more people are on smaller contracts, shorter contracts.
So this dynamism has to be built into the way we think of learners.
The way to think of that in terms of how can you build a strategy for higher education?
I think we can look at the work from a steady I did with Martin Weller and Rob Farrow, which we called so fat in this study.
We said if you look at higher education.
You can actually just say it's really a connection of three.
Key process is the first one is the question of what is.
How do you provide access and delivery of learning opportunities?

So the classic idea is, well, you do that by saying a student has to come to your campus and if we think of an online version you say where you do that by saying the student has to enroll on to a lot online platform.
The second point is learning content.
So what is the content that's being provided for this learning opportunity?
And a very important point, which I think we haven't focused on enough, is recognition and certification.
So there's a lot happening in this area at the moment.

I would say more of the focus is on satification rather than recognition because we tend to think of we're just assessing's, whereas I've already mentioned, particularly with the Group of Transformers.
It's about recognizing what they can already do and building on this.
So if we think of that, I think that's a very helpful way to look at the process as we have in our universities.
And and in each of these three areas to think about what are we doing and what could be we be doing to help the learners who are our target group.
When we do this.
And this is my final slide.
We always have to go back to the question of what are our real goals in higher education, especially going forward.
And so I think.
These four things are probably central.
We have to say we need to ensure that students are acquiring.

Study programs need to reflect on and react to developments in society so.
I focused in my presentation, now very much on labor market demands, but we have other challenges in society as well.
A great way of thinking of these challenges is to think of the sustainable development goals from the UN and it's a huge importance for higher education.
That is a space to reflect on, React and react to these because it should be a place and this is my Third Point.
It should be a place where young people.
And old people.
Anyone who's learning in higher education has the opportunity to almost practice future social reform.
Higher education is a special space of learning where we can kind of think about how should society continue to develop and finally.

If we think about this.

Augmented reality different kind of additive manufacturing, etc.
One way of solving that is to collaborate.

For example with Fab Labs to collaborate with firms which are offering these kind of things so the University doesn't have to offer only things within its kind of own space within its campus, but it can go out and use these learning spaces as well.
Thank you very much for your attention.
Thank you very much for this wonderful presentation.

Otherwise, I have many questions.

Period from I don't know 18 to 24 but we all need to think about our education for for the longer.

So firstly, thank you for picking up on the terminology.
There's two things we were very keen on in the study.
The first is to as much as possible to use the term learner instead of student because it's always a question.
Well, how do you get the status of student and that could be.
It's normally some kind of administrative process like enrollment and we wanted to think kind of.
Let's think a bit more more flexibly about that and the second point is we don't talk about in the study.
We don't talk about universities or colleges, so we don't talk about the institution.
We talk about higher education, and this goes back for me a little bit to a book written about 20 years ago from a professor from the UK, which is where she entitles the idea of higher education.
And this was a big change because mostly when we're thinking about higher education, we've always had the classic books called the idea of the University.
And so This is why we focus very much on higher education, because we're thinking the next question is how to organize that the the the big question for us.
And that's why I kind of had the final slide is if we're thinking that flexibly.
When do we know something is higher education?
So this is a bit to your point that.

If we think of, you know 21st century skills, which at the moment are very much just discussed on in secondary education level, then we have to think about well which kind of level should should students be learning at.
The idea of experimenting, being creative, thinking about how society could be in the future.
This has to, of course start in the kindergarten has to be available in school as well and in University but.
You will see in most debates when we're talking about these GNU demands, particularly when we talk about 21st century skills and and digital.
We're always focusing on the new generation.
And what about the rest of us?
I mean, I'm also not the new generation, you know, and most of us we finished.
Some kind of education, let's say when we were mid 20s or 30s, what about all the rest of the time?

So I think it's important, of course to think about the new challenges in terms of what should we be changing in the schooling system, but I think higher education has got such a huge responsibility because actually higher education is covering everyone from, let's say the 8 of 20 onwards.
And sometimes we don't think about that.
'cause we focus too much on the 18th.
2 year olds.
Thank you, I have another question.
I notice that you mentioned also in employers that these should also influence the system.
Do you have any idea how to actually implement this?
How do you do this in German for instance?

So this is a this idea that employers and and higher education providers should be working much closer together is really mostly to do with the debates we see all the time in the newspapers where universities are being criticised and not providing what the employers want.
My opinion is the labor market has become lazy.
They just say education should be providing everything and then we just want everyone to be perfect and then we put them in a job and they work.
That doesn't work in a learning society either.
Everyone is part of a learning society including the employers.
We are beginning to have this change, so one of the examples we provide in our study is a very big bank based in Norway.
They have 10,000 employers employees sorry and for their their current strategy they have four columns of how they want to move forward.
One of those columns is skills enhancement and what they've realized is it's becoming very difficult to use.
The old way of human resource is, which is essentially OK. My business is changing, and of course in banking things are changing very fast.
Now the old idea is my business is changing.
Now I have a gap I need.
People with a certain skills profile to fill this gap.
So in banking, banking has become much more about data analysis.
For example, an offering data supported services.
In the past you would just say, right?
Let's just do an advert for this and let's try and recruit.
As I've said, a kind of ready made person.
The banks have realized in the DMV specifically this is super expensive and it's a waste of the people I've already.
I'm already employing, so they're focusing on skills development and they're doing this by working with educational providers.

The disappointing part of this story is they found that the universities have been the least flexible partners, so they've actually started developing something which only sees a very small role for higher education, and I I talked to the Director for Learning Development at this bank, and she said in the past what would happen is if we wanted to.

If we if we wanted to kind of upskill our employees, we would send our student away or send our employer away to do like a Bachelor or master course and they said we don't do this anymore because what was coming back wasn't exactly what we wanted.

So now we work much more closely with the providers, but she said what we do is we designed the course and then we go to the University and say have you got someone who could provide this and this program for us based on what we think we need.
I was disappointed when I heard that because I think it should be the role of higher education to be much more actively involved in this.
So this is, I think, both a challenge for employers to think much more about skills development instead of just complaining about skills gaps.

But I think it's a challenge for higher education as well to try and put ourselves in the position of employers as well and try and think about what exactly do they need instead of saying well, look, I've got, you know.
10 programs which I think will work.
Which of those 10 are you going to take?
Because that idea is is also not to the flexibility I was talking about here.
OK, thank you so much.
I will keep my questions for tomorrow.
One question concerning learners motivation to be included.
Is this only the pressure of the market or we should prepare people to really include it because they need to get new knowledge or how we can manage to get them actively inside?
So I so the question is about, yeah motivation.

I think of of learners and particularly, you know I focused a lot in my work in the past on on what we sometimes call vulnerable groups are under represented groups and we often find their motivation is also lacking, but it's lacking because they've had very bad experience in the education system.
So part of the way we ensure their motivation is we recognize what these people have achieved so far and try and kind of pull them into the system.
But the the I think motivation and self organization are both very key elements that you mentioned because the other point is.

We find that purely digital offers also offers of most of the open universities are mostly taken up by people who've already achieved higher education, so they already have this kind of skill to learning, so this is something we have to be providing in our school system, but it's something that we also as higher education providers have to think about how we can support students more, and the problem of this kind of support until now has been it's not really scalable, so.
Some of us might do these great things of you know, supporting individual students, but it's difficult to expand that then to all of your students.
And there I think going forward things like you know the application of artificial intelligence into systems can help that to some extent, but it's a huge challenge.
I totally agree with you.
If you would have unlimited financial and human resources, what would be your Blue Sky project?
Unlimited did you say yeah well?

Exactly this point actually have how to how to enable the kind of support that students need in a way that it that it's scalable, and I think because for me, that's the biggest challenge and that's why I mentioned already that thinking about support and advice as part of the didactical package is super important, and we've tended to think about that in using the term pedagogy when we think about schooling.
But very often we don't think about it on a tertiary education level because we think.
Well, they're already adults.
They should be able to do it, but particularly now this is such an important aspect, so it's mentioned very briefly that I'm working for Kieran and we've got a platform which is to support refugees.

We're going through exactly this transition point at the moment as well, so we had a lot of personal support for our individual students, but we've notice it's not scalable, and therefore we can't offer our services to more and more refugees is, which is what we want.
So this is we need this technical solution for this, but I think the whole point is to think about what the big problem is first and then think how technology can help.
We tend to normally think the other way around.
Oh, OK, now we've got AI.
What can it do?
I don't agree with that way, but that would be my blue Sky sync so.
Give me the money, let's do it.
You mentioned the lack of flexibility of the universities in designing the study programs, but I argue that things are a little bit more complicated than that.

In Europe, and I know for a fact in Slovenia we developed extremely complicated and sophisticated system of evaluation of this quality of the study programs and you if you add to that the mechanisms run by the government in ministries of financing.
Basically you lock the creativity of the University and hinder severely the flexibility when it comes to designing new programs.
So I think we should.
I think a little bit more broader picture in easing the design of new programs.
I totally agree with you, this is something I also mentioned yesterday.
My so before I started working on this and also focusing on vulnerable groups, I was very focused on the whole questions of governance and I've been doing it for the last 20 years.

When we started all of this with this was called new public management and it was really to do with the fact of let's give universities more autonomy in terms of less dirigiste IK control directly from ministries and then kind of the other side was OK.
Therefore we need quality assurance.
And you mentioned the funding as well.
We need for example, performance based funding.
I think we're at a stage now where this has all gone too far and we wrote a.
We wrote an article myself and a colleague from Canada last year, which was to do with.
We looked at the indicators being used for performance based funding and asked ourselves what is the implicit understanding of student success.
And essentially what's happening is some of these systems.

They're just stopping universities being more flexible as you say, so one of the things is if you have performance based funding, which is based on graduate numbers, which seems at first instance very, very sensible.
What you're saying is, you're only going to pay that University once the student has been through all the different years of their study and finally finished their Bachelor or their Masters.

This is this is there's there's no incentive.
Therefore universities to offer that kind of thing because they say, well, we're only going to be paid for graduates, so we want to keep the students as long as possible.
So a lot of these governance methods that have been implemented until now have started to really reduce the flexibility of University.
So I agree with that.
I think in terms of quality assurance there is currently in many countries.

A new development to say, well, maybe we should really think about it, so I've been in discussions with some quality assurance agencies about this, so I think there's a recognition of the problem, but I think you know we've had 20 years or so of this new public management.
It's really the time that we rethink it now and think, how do we?
How can we allow universities to be more flexible?
Thank you very much.

You have one more Twitter followers.
Yeah, otherwise, thank you.
Thank you very much for your attention.
You can of course ask me questions.
